title: Wish Upon a Satellite (Easy Version)
statementHtml:
This is the easy version of the problem. The difference between the versions is that in this version, t≤1000t≤1000, n≤5000n≤5000 and the sum of nn does not exceed 50005000. You can hack only if you solved all versions of this problem.

For a non-empty sequence cc of length kk, define f(c)f(c) as follows:

For a permutation pp of length nn∗∗, Turtle defines the beauty of the permutation as n∑i=1n∑j=if([pi,pi+1,…,pj])∑i=1n∑j=inf([pi,pi+1,…,pj]) (i.e., the sum of f(c)f(c) where cc is a non-empty subsegment†† of pp).

Piggy gives Turtle a permutation aa of length nn where some elements are missing and represented by 00.

Turtle asks you to determine a permutation bb of length nn such that:

For convenience, you only need to find the maximum beauty of such permutation bb.

∗∗A permutation of length nn is an array consisting of nn distinct integers from 11 to nn in arbitrary order. For example, [2,3,1,5,4][2,3,1,5,4] is a permutation, but [1,2,2][1,2,2] is not a permutation (22 appears twice in the array), and [1,3,4][1,3,4] is also not a permutation (n=3n=3 but there is 44 in the array).

††A sequence aa is a subsegment of a sequence bb if aa can be obtained from bb by the deletion of several (possibly, zero or all) elements from the beginning and several (possibly, zero or all) elements from the end.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤10001≤t≤1000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤50001≤n≤5000).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (0≤ai≤n0≤ai≤n). It is guaranteed that the elements of aa that are not 00 are distinct.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 50005000.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer — the maximum beauty of the permutation bb.
noteHtml:
In the first test case, the permutation bb with the maximum beauty is [1,2][1,2]. The beauty of [1,2][1,2] is 44 since f([1])+f([2])+f([1,2])=1+2+1=4f([1])+f([2])+f([1,2])=1+2+1=4. If c=[1,2]c=[1,2], then f(c)=1f(c)=1 since Turtle can only choose i=1i=1 and he will set c1c1 to min(c1,c2)=1min(c1,c2)=1.

In the second test case, one of the permutations bb with the maximum beauty is [3,2,1][3,2,1]. The beauty of [3,2,1][3,2,1] is 1212 since f([3])+f([2])+f([1])+f([3,2])+f([2,1])+f([3,2,1])=3+2+1+2+1+3=12f([3])+f([2])+f([1])+f([3,2])+f([2,1])+f([3,2,1])=3+2+1+2+1+3=12.

In the third test case, one of the permutations bb with the maximum beauty is [2,1,3][2,1,3].

In the fourth test case, if c=[3,2,4,5,1]c=[3,2,4,5,1], then f(c)=3f(c)=3. One of the possible game processes is as follows:

  • Turtle can choose i=3i=3. Then he will set c3c3 to min(c3,c4)=4min(c3,c4)=4 and remove c4c4. The sequence cc will become [3,2,4,1][3,2,4,1].
  • Piggy can choose i=1i=1. Then he will set c1c1 to max(c1,c2)=3max(c1,c2)=3 and remove c2c2. The sequence cc will become [3,4,1][3,4,1].
  • Turtle can choose i=2i=2. Then he will set c2c2 to min(c2,c3)=1min(c2,c3)=1 and remove c3c3. The sequence cc will become [3,1][3,1].
  • Piggy can choose i=1i=1. Then he will set c1c1 to max(c1,c2)=3max(c1,c2)=3 and remove c2c2. The sequence cc will become [3][3].
  • The length of the sequence becomes 11, so the game will end. The value of c1c1 will be 33 in the end.

In the fifth test case, one of the permutations bb with the maximum beauty is [1,3,2,5,6,4,7][1,3,2,5,6,4,7].
tutorialHtml:
First, we have

f(c)={min(c1,ck)kmod2=0max(c1,ck)kmod2=1

Symmetrically, let g(c) be the result when the order of the first and second players is swapped. Then,

g(c)={max(c1,ck)kmod2=0min(c1,ck)kmod2=1

Proof: Consider an inductive approach. The base case k≤2 is evident. For k≥3, consider computing f(c). Assume k is odd. If the first player chooses 2≤i≤k−2, the game reduces to g(c′), and the answer is max(c1,ck). If the first player chooses i=1 or i=k−1, the answer is at most max(c1,ck). Other cases follow similarly.

Thus, for a permutation p1,p2,…,pn, we have

n∑i=1n∑j=if([pi,pi+1,…,pj])=n∑i=1n∑j=i([imod2=jmod2]max(pi,pj)+[imod2≠jmod2]min(pi,pj))=n∑i=1n∑j=imax(pi,pj)−n∑i=1n∑j=i+1[imod2≠jmod2](max(pi,pj)−min(pi,pj))=n∑i=1i2−n∑i=1n∑j=i+1[imod2≠jmod2]|pi−pj|

Thus, the problem reduces to minimizing the following expression:

n∑i=1n∑j=i+1[imod2≠jmod2]|bi−bj|

This can be further transformed into a problem involving a number line from 1 to n, where point i can be black, white, or undetermined. If i is at an odd index in sequence a, it is black; if even, it is white. If i does not appear in a, it is undetermined. Our goal is to color the undetermined points as either black or white such that:

  • There are exactly ⌈n2⌉ black points.
  • The sum of distances between all pairs of differently colored points is minimized.

This sum can be rewritten as: for each 1≤k<n, the number of black points in 1∼k times the number of white points in k+1∼n, plus the number of white points in 1∼k times the number of black points in k+1∼n.

This reformulated problem can be solved using DP. Define fi,j as the minimum possible sum of the above distances when 1≤k<i after determining the colors of the first i points, with exactly j black points.

For transitions, first update fi,j by adding the contribution from k=i. That is to add j×(⌊n2⌋−(i−j))+(i−j)×(⌈n2⌉−j) to all fi,j.

Then, consider whether the (i+1)-th point is black or white:

  • If it can be white, then perform fi+1,j=min(fi+1,j,fi,j).
  • If it can be black, then perform fi+1,j+1=min(fi+1,j+1,fi,j).

The final answer is n∑i=1i2−fn,⌈n2⌉.

Time complexity: O(n2) per test case.
